Award.AwardTitle: Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site: Training and Research Experiences in Nonlinear Dynamics (TREND)
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the continuation of the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program at the University of Maryland College Park. The main goal of the program will be to introduce undergraduate students to the university research environment through participation in frontier research. Participating undergraduates become members of research groups and are mentored by faculty members, post-docs and graduate students. Students see first-hand and participate directly in the research process. Past research topics have included: nano-photonic devices, spatio-temporal chaos and synchronism of chaotic systems, chaotic microwave circuits, dynamics of granular media, development of singularities in fluids and solids, nonlinear dynamics in optical systems and charged particle beams, magnetic reconnection, and turbulence and nonlinear phenomena in plasmas. Seminar series will complement and reinforce the learning experience. Student projects and presentations will be judged on the final day of the program, and winners will be funded to present their work at a relevant national conference. In addition, the summer program offers seminars and trips that expose students to a wide variety of subjects and opportunities. This will likely include trips to nearby government research laboratories, and lectures on topics such as applying to graduate school.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The TREND (Training and Research Experiences in Nonlinear Dyanmics) REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) program is a physics-focused summer program at University of Maryland, College Park (UMD). Its main goal is to expose undergraduate students to the university research environment by immersive participation in frontier research. Between 2012 and 2015, TREND mentored 40 undergraduate students, 21 of which belong to groups underrepresented in Physics. This included 15 female students and 7 student identifying as ethnic or racial minorities. Approximately half of the participants had just completed their junior years and the remaining half were a mix of a freshman and sophomores.

The TREND program is housed at UMD’s Institute for Research in Electronics and Applied Physics. Thanks to this affiliation, the program can offer a diverse set of research topics to our undergraduate participants: the dynamics of living cells, underwater vehicle motion guidance, turbulence and fluid flow, charged particle beams, socialand biological networks. Depending on their project, students do experiments, theoretical work, computational work, or a combination of these, under mentorship of UMD faculty with additional guidance from post docs and graduate students.

Besides the research efforts, students also engage in professional development activities. A weekly seminar series alternates scientific talks by researchers of diverse professional backgrounds with skills-based talks. Outreach activities provide interaction with middle and high school students. A Research Fair at the end of the summer is a forum to deliver poster and oral presentations to peers and mentors. The research efforts of these outstanding students have impact outside of UMD: 7 publications in academic journals and 16 presentations at professional conferences have resulted from their work. This includes important avenues like the American Physical Society March Meeting and Physical Review Letters.

TREND’s intellectual impact is manifested in the training of 40 undergraduate participants in non-linear dynamics, and the knowledge that training has imparted, as they’ve moved through their academic careers at their respective institutions, and their future graduate schoolwork and professional careers. TREND’s broader impact will be seen as this diverse group of students matures into scientists and engineers that have been exposed to research, communication and outreach opportunities.
